definition:
Let $G$ be a group, $X$ a set on which it acts. Let $X^{(n)}$ be the set
of order $n$-tuples of distinct elements of $X$. This is a $G$-set by
the diagonal action:
$$g\cdot (x_1,\ldots,x_n)=(g\cdot x_1,\ldots,g\cdot x_n)$$

The action of $G$ on $X$ is said to be $n$-transitive if it acts
transitively on $X^{(n)}$.

For example, the standard action of $S^n$, the symmetric group, is
$n$-transitive, and the standard action of $A_n$, the alternating group,
is $(n-2)$-transitive.
